item.title: Learning Matplotlib
item.dc:creator: Shankar Muthuswamy
item.description:
This is one of my documented learning sessions trying out plotting with Matplotlib. Everything below consists of things I've learnt perusing some wonderful educational blogs. Hope you find this useful.

In [6]: 
from pylab import *
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
%matplotlib inline
In [2]: 
x = linspace(0, 5, 10)
y=x**2
In [7]: 
#simple MATLAB like plotting technique. pylab module helps with this.
figure()
plot(x,y,'b')
xlabel('x')
ylabel('y')
title('title')
show()
In [25]: 
#subplot controls how many plots we want to keep. 1,2 says 1 row and 2 cols for plotting.
#r-- makes it a red dashed line
subplot(1,2,1)
plot(x,y,'r--')
xlabel('Chart1')
subplot(1,2,2)
plot(y,x,'b*-')
xlabel('Chart2')
Out[25]:
<matplotlib.text.Text at 0x7ff31e8c5fd0>
In [35]: 
#MPL adds obj-oriented style so gives more control. Nothing is global...
fig = plt.figure()
axes = fig.add_axes([0.1,0.1,0.8,0.8]) #left,bottom, width, height
axes.plot(x,y,'r')
axes.set_xlabel('MatPlotX')
axes.set_ylabel('MatPlotY')
axes.set_title('New Title')
plt.show()
In [41]: 
fig = plt.figure()
axes1 = fig.add_axes([0.1,0.1,0.8,0.8]) #left,bottom, width, height
axes2 = fig.add_axes([0.2,0.5,0.4,0.3]) 
axes1.plot(x,y,'r')
axes1.set_xlabel('MatPlotX')
axes1.set_ylabel('MatPlotY')
axes1.set_title('New Title')
axes2.plot(y,x,'b--')
axes2.set_xlabel('InPlotX')
axes2.set_ylabel('InPlotY')
axes2.set_title('In Title')
plt.show()
In [43]: 
#If we don't care about precisely placing the plots, we can use an axis manager, like subplots
fig, axes = plt.subplots(nrows = 1, ncols = 2)
for ax in axes:
    ax.plot(x,y,'g--')
    ax.set_xlabel('MatPlotX')
    ax.set_ylabel('MatPlotY')
    ax.set_title ('MatTitle')
In [52]: 
#tight layout method helps fix overlapping titles and labels
fig, axes = plt.subplots(nrows = 1, ncols = 2)
for ax in axes:
    ax.plot(x,y,'g--')
    ax.set_xlabel('MatPlotX')
    ax.set_ylabel('MatPlotY')
    ax.set_title ('MatTitle')
fig.tight_layout()
In [57]: 
#We can specify height and width of the entire plot in inches and dpi (dots per inch) while creating the Figure object.
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(8,5),dpi=100)
axes = fig.add_axes([0.1,0.1,0.8,0.8]) #left,bottom, width, height
axes.plot(x,y,'r')
axes.set_xlabel('MatPlotX')
axes.set_ylabel('MatPlotY')
axes.set_title('New Title')
plt.show()
In [60]: 
#figsize can also be specified for subplots
fig, axes = plt.subplots(figsize=(8,5),dpi=100, nrows = 1, ncols = 2)
for ax in axes:
    ax.plot(x,y,'g--')
    ax.set_xlabel('MatPlotX')
    ax.set_ylabel('MatPlotY')
    ax.set_title ('MatTitle')
fig.tight_layout()
In [62]: 
#To save a figure, optionally, dpi can also be specified here
#Multiple formats available - PNG, JPG, EPS, SVG, PGF and PDF
fig.savefig("File1.png", dpi=200)
fig.savefig("File1.pdf", dpi=200)
In [63]: 
#Title
ax.set_title("title");
#Axis labels
ax.set_xlabel("x")
ax.set_ylabel("y");
#Legend
ax.legend(["curve1", "curve2", "curve3"]);
#The above method is prone to errors since it's equivalent to hardcoding. Below works better. 
ax.plot(x, x**2, label="curve1")
ax.plot(x, x**3, label="curve2")
ax.legend();
#This method updates the legend automatically if curves are removed/added
#legend() has an optional loc argument specifying location
ax.legend(loc=0) # let matplotlib decide the optimal location
ax.legend(loc=1) # upper right corner
ax.legend(loc=2) # upper left corner
ax.legend(loc=3) # lower left corner
ax.legend(loc=4) # lower right corner
# .. many more options are available
Out[63]:
<matplotlib.legend.Legend at 0x7ff31defdb50>
In [71]: 
#Using Legend
fig, ax=plt.subplots()
ax.plot(x,x**3,'g', label="y = x**3")
ax.plot(x,x**4,'b', label="y = x**4")
ax.set_xlabel('x')
ax.set_ylabel('y')
ax.legend(loc=2) #Top left
plt.show()
In [76]: 
#LaTeX symbols can be added enclosing wiht $. Also the backslash in LaTeX symbols should be included within
#the raw text format r'\alpha' otherwise \ will be interepreted as an escape symbol
fig, ax=plt.subplots()
ax.plot(x,x**3,'g', label=r"$y = \alpha^3$")
ax.plot(x,x**4,'b', label=r"$y = \alpha^4$")
ax.set_xlabel('$x$')
ax.set_ylabel('$y$')
ax.set_title('Title')
ax.legend(loc=2) #Top left
plt.show()
In [81]: 
#We can also change the global font size and family
matplotlib.rcParams.update({'font.size': 18, 'font.family': 'serif'})

#Can also ask MPL to use LaTeX to render all text
#matplotlib.rcParams.update({'font.size': 18, 'text.usetex': True})
#Can be set back to False once done
In [83]: 
#replotting
fig, ax=plt.subplots()
ax.plot(x,x**3,'g', label=r"$y = \alpha^3$")
ax.plot(x,x**4,'b', label=r"$y = \alpha^4$")
ax.set_xlabel(r'$\alpha$')
ax.set_ylabel('$y$')
ax.set_title('Title')
ax.legend(loc=2) #Top left
plt.show()
In [86]: 
matplotlib.rcParams.update({'font.size': 14, 'font.family': 'serif'})
#Colors
fig, ax = plt.subplots()

ax.plot(x, x+1, color="red", alpha=0.5) # half-transparant red, alpha controls transparency
ax.plot(x, x+2, color="#1155dd")        # RGB hex code for a bluish color
ax.plot(x, x+3, color="#15cc55")        # RGB hex code for a greenish color
plt.show()
In [118]: 
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12,6))

#Linewidth settings, lw or linewidth
ax.plot(x, x+1, color="blue", linewidth=0.25)
ax.plot(x, x+2, color="blue", linewidth=0.50)
ax.plot(x, x+3, color="blue", linewidth=1.00)
ax.plot(x, x+4, 'b', linewidth=2.00)

# possible linestype options ‘-‘, ‘–’, ‘-.’, ‘:’, ‘steps’, ls or linestyle
ax.plot(x, x+5, color="red", lw=2, linestyle='-')
ax.plot(x, x+6, color="red", lw=2, ls='-.')
ax.plot(x, x+7, color="red", lw=2, ls=':')

#custom dash
line, = ax.plot(x, x+8, color="black", lw=1.50)
line.set_dashes([5, 10, 15, 10]) # format: line length, space length, ...

# possible marker symbols: marker = '+', 'o', '*', 's', ',', '.', '1', '2', '3', '4', ...
ax.plot(x, x+ 9, color="green", lw=2, ls='*', marker='+')
ax.plot(x, x+10, color="green", lw=2, ls='*', marker='o')
ax.plot(x, x+11, color="green", lw=2, ls='*', marker='s')
ax.plot(x, x+12, color="green", lw=2, ls='*', marker='4')
ax.plot(x, x+13, color="green", lw=2, ls='-', marker='o')

# marker size and color
ax.plot(x, x+14, color="purple", lw=1, ls='-', marker='o', markersize=2)
ax.plot(x, x+15, color="purple", lw=1, ls='-', marker='o', markersize=4)
ax.plot(x, x+16, color="purple", lw=1, ls='-', marker='o', markersize=5, markerfacecolor="red")
ax.plot(x, x+17, color="purple", lw=1, ls='-', marker='s', markersize=8, 
        markerfacecolor="yellow", markeredgewidth=2, markeredgecolor="blue");

plt.show()
In [119]: 
#Plot Axes, xlim and ylim can be used to set scales
#Note nrows and ncols are optional keywords, we can just specify values
fig, axes = plt.subplots(1, 3, figsize=(12, 4))

#note continuous plotting style, x,y,x1,y1
axes[0].plot(x, x**2, x, x**3)
axes[0].set_title("default axes ranges")

axes[1].plot(x, x**2, x, x**3)
#Sets tight axis, fit to perfection
axes[1].axis('tight')
axes[1].set_title("tight axes")

axes[2].plot(x, x**2, x, x**3)
axes[2].set_ylim([0, 60])
axes[2].set_xlim([2, 5])
axes[2].set_title("custom axes range");
In [120]: 
#Setting log scale
fig, axes = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(10,4))
      
axes[0].plot(x, x**2, x, exp(x))
axes[0].set_title("Normal scale")

axes[1].plot(x, x**2, x, exp(x))
axes[1].set_yscale("log")
axes[1].set_title("Logarithmic scale (y)");
In [122]: 
#Ticks and tick labels. Pick where the ticks should be and also assign custom labels for each tick.
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 4))

ax.plot(x, x**2, x, x**3, lw=2)

#Tick locations
ax.set_xticks([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
#Tick labels for each location
ax.set_xticklabels([r'$\alpha$', r'$\beta$', r'$\gamma$', r'$\delta$', r'$\epsilon$'], fontsize=18)

yticks = [0, 50, 100, 150]
ax.set_yticks(yticks)
#Formatting the yticks
ax.set_yticklabels(["$%.1f$" % y for y in yticks], fontsize=18); # use LaTeX formatted labels
plt.show()
In [123]: 
#Scientific notation
fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1)
      
ax.plot(x, x**2, x, exp(x))
ax.set_title("scientific notation")

ax.set_yticks([0, 50, 100, 150])

from matplotlib import ticker
formatter = ticker.ScalarFormatter(useMathText=True)
formatter.set_scientific(True) 
formatter.set_powerlimits((-1,1)) 
ax.yaxis.set_major_formatter(formatter)
In [133]: 
# distance between x and y axis and the numbers on the axes, how close the numbers appear to the borders
rcParams['xtick.major.pad'] = 5
rcParams['ytick.major.pad'] = 5

fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1)
      
ax.plot(x, x**2, x, exp(x))
ax.set_yticks([0, 50, 100, 150])

ax.set_title("label and axis spacing")

# padding between axis label and axis numbers
ax.xaxis.labelpad = 5
ax.yaxis.labelpad = 5

ax.set_xlabel("x")
ax.set_ylabel("y");
In [142]: 
#Axis position adjustments - if we need to move the figures a bit to avoid clipping when saving...

fig, ax = plt.subplots(1, 1)
      
ax.plot(x, x**2, x, exp(x))
ax.set_yticks([0, 50, 100, 150])

ax.set_title("title")
ax.set_xlabel("x")
ax.set_ylabel("y")

fig.subplots_adjust(left=0.15, right=.9, bottom=0.1, top=0.9);
In [146]: 
#Grid Lines, we can turn it on/off and also format it

fig, axes = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(10,3))

# default grid appearance
axes[0].plot(x, x**2, x, x**3, lw=2)
axes[0].grid(True)

# custom grid appearance
axes[1].plot(x, x**2, x, x**3, lw=2)
axes[1].grid(color='b', alpha=0.5, linestyle='dashed', linewidth=0.5)
In [147]: 
#Formatting plot borders...
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(6,2))

ax.spines['bottom'].set_color('blue')
ax.spines['top'].set_color('blue')

ax.spines['left'].set_color('red')
ax.spines['left'].set_linewidth(2)

# turn off axis spine to the right
ax.spines['right'].set_color("none")
ax.yaxis.tick_left() # only ticks on the left side
In [154]: 
#Dual Axis plotting...using twinx method
fig, ax1 = plt.subplots()

ax1.plot(x, x**2, lw=2, color="blue")
ax1.set_ylabel(r"area $(m^2)$", fontsize=18, color="blue")
#Observe get labels method, to retrieve all lables along an axis. 
for label in ax1.get_yticklabels():
      label.set_color("blue")

#twinx to plot on same graph but diff axis
ax2 = ax1.twinx()
ax2.plot(x, x**3, lw=2, color="red")
ax2.set_ylabel(r"volume $(m^3)$", fontsize=18, color="red")
for label in ax2.get_yticklabels():
    label.set_color("red")
In [155]: 
#Axis formatting example
fig, ax1 = plt.subplots()

ax1.plot(x, x**2, lw=2, color="blue")
ax1.set_ylabel(r"area $(m^2)$", fontsize=18, color="blue")
#Observe get labels method, to retrieve all lables along an axis. 
i=0
for label in ax1.get_yticklabels():
      i+=1
      if i==4:
         label.set_color("red")
      else:
         label.set_color("blue")
In [160]: 
#Moving the x and y axis along the plot
fig, ax = plt.subplots()

ax.spines['right'].set_color('none')
ax.spines['top'].set_color('none')

ax.xaxis.set_ticks_position('bottom')
#Controls where the x axis is displayed
ax.spines['bottom'].set_position(('data',0)) # set position of x spine to x=0

ax.yaxis.set_ticks_position('left')
#Controls where the y axis is displayed
ax.spines['left'].set_position(('data',0))   # set position of y spine to y=0

xx = np.linspace(-0.75, 1., 100)
ax.plot(xx, xx**3);
In [176]: 
#Other 2D Plots - Scatter, Step, Bar, Fill Between

n = array([0,1,2,3,4,5])
fig, axes = plt.subplots(1, 4, figsize=(12,3))

axes[0].scatter(xx, xx + 0.25*randn(len(xx)))
axes[0].set_title("scatter")

axes[1].step(n, n**2, lw=2)
axes[1].set_title("step")

axes[2].bar(n, n**2, align="center", width=0.5, alpha=0.5)
axes[2].set_title("bar")

axes[3].fill_between(x, x**2, x**3, color="green", alpha=0.5);
axes[3].set_title("fill_between");

fig.tight_layout()
In [180]: 
#Histograms
n = np.random.randn(100000)
fig, axes = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(12,4))

axes[0].hist(n)
axes[0].set_title("Default histogram")
axes[0].set_xlim((min(n), max(n)))

axes[1].hist(n, cumulative=True, bins=50)
axes[1].set_title("Cumulative detailed histogram")
axes[1].set_xlim((min(n), max(n)));
In [193]: 
#Text Annotation using the "text" function
fig, ax = plt.subplots()

ax.plot(xx, xx**2, xx, xx**3)

ax.text(0.15, 0.2, r"$y=x^2$", fontsize=20, color="b")
ax.text(0.65, 0.1, r"$y=x^3$", fontsize=20, color="green");
In [196]: 
#Multiple subplots and insets
#Add axes manually adds axes. Layout manager like subplots, subplot2grid, gridspec can also be used.

#subplots
fig, ax = plt.subplots(2, 3, figsize=(12,6))
fig.tight_layout()
In [206]: 
#subplot2grid
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(10,6))
#Specifies where each plot starts and how many cols or rows it spans
ax1 = plt.subplot2grid((3,3), (0,0), colspan=3)
ax2 = plt.subplot2grid((3,3), (1,0), colspan=2)
ax3 = plt.subplot2grid((3,3), (1,2), rowspan=2)
ax4 = plt.subplot2grid((3,3), (2,0))
ax5 = plt.subplot2grid((3,3), (2,1))
fig.tight_layout()
In [210]: 
#Manually adding axes is useful for insets
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(12,6))
ax.plot(xx, xx**2, xx, xx**3)
fig.tight_layout()

# inset
inset_ax = fig.add_axes([0.2, 0.55, 0.35, 0.35]) # X, Y, width, height

inset_ax.plot(xx, xx**2, xx, xx**3)
inset_ax.set_title('zoom near origin')

# set axis range
inset_ax.set_xlim(-.2, .2)
inset_ax.set_ylim(-.005, .01)

# set axis tick locations
inset_ax.set_yticks([0, 0.005, 0.01])
inset_ax.set_xticks([-0.1,0,.1]);
In [211]: 
#Colormaps and Colorbars
alpha = 0.7
phi_ext = 2 * pi * 0.5

def flux_qubit_potential(phi_m, phi_p):
    return 2 + alpha - 2 * cos(phi_p)*cos(phi_m) - alpha * cos(phi_ext - 2*phi_p)
In [219]: 
phi_m = linspace(0, 2*pi, 100)
phi_p = linspace(0, 2*pi, 100)
X,Y = meshgrid(phi_p, phi_m)
Z = flux_qubit_potential(X, Y).T
In [227]: 
#Using pcolor (pcolormesh is faster for larger arrays) to display colormaps
#cmap= specifies type of colormap, hit tab to see types
fig, ax = plt.subplots()

p = ax.pcolormesh(X/(2*pi), Y/(2*pi), Z, cmap=cm.Accent, vmin=abs(Z).min(), vmax=abs(Z).max())
cb = fig.colorbar(p, ax=ax)
#Note the colorbar command. ax=ax is a standard parameter.
In [232]: 
#Using imshow
fig, ax = plt.subplots()

im = ax.imshow(Z, cmap=cm.RdBu, vmin=abs(Z).min(), vmax=abs(Z).max(), extent=[0, 1, 0, 1])
im.set_interpolation('bilinear')

cb = fig.colorbar(im, ax=ax)
In [233]: 
#contour plots
fig, ax = plt.subplots()

cnt = ax.contour(Z, cmap=cm.RdBu, vmin=abs(Z).min(), vmax=abs(Z).max(), extent=[0, 1, 0, 1])
In []:
